title: I have a question regarding Chapter 7 and my current employment status
question: I have over $30,000 in credit card debt (which I have previously settled and have started 5-7 year payment plans. Unfortunately, due to a mental illness for the past 6 mths I was careless with bills, spending, etc. Past 3 mths been getting treatment and trying to pick up the pieces.. I went from $5,000 a month (before taxes) to collecting NDI disability from work ($250 a week). Before,I was always just breaking even each month. Now I am very far behind in finances and cant afford to live in CA anymore and moving to FL to live with a relative. The creditors are not willing to put me back on the payment plan and are harassing me to pay the full amounts in full. I do not have property, furniture, etc. I have $150 in my bank acct. I am moving to FL w/out a job. Do u advise Chapter 7?
question_tags: Child support,Alimony,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy means test,Chapter 13 bankruptcy,Credit,Chapter 13 bankruptcy repayment plan,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Nondischargeable debt and alimony,Secured debt,Unsecured debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Chapter 13 bankruptcy reorganization plan,Employment
answers:
I agree with the answer above except you do not have to wait 180 days to file your Chapter 7 in Florida. You can either file it here in CA or FL if you have resided in FL for the greater part of the last 180 days. That means you have to be in FL for 91 days not the 180 days as indicated above.

Once you move to Florida and have been here for at least 180 days you should be able to file a chapter 7 in the State of Florida. As long as you have not filed for a chapter 7 in the last 8 years or a chapter 13 in the last 4 years. Based on the information that you have provided it would seem that you would pass the means test. This chapter 7 will discharge all of your unsecured debt and any secured debt in which you are surrendering the property. The only debts you will not be able to discharge would be taxes, child support, alimony, student loans, etc. I believe it would be more beneficial to file for a chapter 7 and get a clean slate then try to continue to negociate with the credit card companies.
